And now: we couldn't really meet,

without confronting the issue that

That of forced migration

Alexander Betts is a renowned expert

He works here in Oxford

sorry to say, greatly in demand

I've read him over the years,

It is my very great honor

One of the strange things

and nobody is very interested

And with that, despite the tragedy,

And that's why I'm not only delighted

108.92.text:
including hundreds of children

But to change that we need

talents and aspirations of refugees,

I want to lay out a vision

211.10.text:
in a reception centre where

And while there I wasn't doing

and organizing games and activities

What I'd expected was to feel

In my evenings I had extraordinary

until they can wait for many years

And that to me was just

And so when I came away from that

and travelled to refugee camps
around the world,

274.87.text:
the problem was
that that scenario replicated.

279.34.text: From Kenya to Tanzania, to Thailand.

282.99.text:
I discovered that the world's response
to refugees

286.30.text:
was effectively to warehouse them
in refugee camps

292.10.text:
People are born into camps,
they grow up in camps,

296.30.text:
And today the average length of time

300.62.text:
in these situations is nearly

304.29.text:
To give you an example,
this is the Ali-Addeh refugee camp

308.53.text:
and it's on the border

312.22.text:
It's home to around 10,000 people,

Many have been there since

And one person was this guy Wuli

331.76.text:
he was one of the first people

And Wuli told me, "Man doesn't live

340.83.text:
My hope is gone but I pass it
to the next generation."

344.91.text:
And what he does in a camp with
very little post-primary education

348.93.text:
is informal education

352.51.text:
He teaches English and maths and

357.46.text: But Wuli should also have hope.

360.27.text:
It shouldn't just be that he has

363.50.text:
And I think this situation
that we see around the world,

366.40.text:
of protracted refugee situations,
does not have to be inevitable.

371.18.text:
So with my team in Oxford
we've embarked on research

374.33.text:
looking at the economic lives
of refugees,

377.25.text:
trying to rethink refugees
as a potential resource

381.35.text:
rather than this view that they have
to be a cost and a burden.

385.86.text:
And we chose to start our work
in Uganda,

388.81.text:
not because it's representative
of refugee hosting countries,

394.65.text:
Uganda has embarked on an
experiment in how it treats refugees,

399.69.text:
in what it calls a self-reliance strategy.
It gives refugee the right to work

406.49.text:
So it shows the contributions
refugees can make

408.89.text:
if they're given basic
economic opportunities.

412.34.text:
And we undertook that research
over a number of years

415.34.text:
doing qualitative work
and quantitative work,

417.57.text:
trying to marry human stories

422.56.text:
And as is characteristic of our work,

426.44.text:
We built a team of peer

432.35.text:
Somalis, Congolese, Rwandans,
men and women,

436.21.text:
to enhance our access
to the communities

438.28.text:
and build relationships of trust
and build a legacy

441.85.text:
that these people could take
that training onwards.

444.85.text:
But what we found in the research
was incredible.

447.29.text:
Our work challenges
five basic assumptions

453.29.text: and the world's response to refugees.

455.43.text:
The first of those is the myth
that refugees

458.62.text:
are economically isolated
even in camps and closed settlements.

463.58.text:
This photograph illustrates
a Congolese ceremonial fabric

467.47.text:
called Bitenge. It's used for weddings

471.01.text: And when we asked an NGO worker

473.35.text:
who works in this settlement in Uganda,
the Nakivale settlement,

478.29.text:
We were told it probably
comes across the border

481.08.text: from the Democratic Republic of Congo.

483.39.text:
When we asked refugees themselves,
we got a very different answer.

487.69.text:
They told us it came from as far afield

494.06.text:
imported through refugee-run value
chains to the Owino Market in Kampala

498.58.text:
moved across road networks
to cities, Hoima and Mbarara,

502.17.text:
near the refugee settlements
where it's sold and distributed.

506.05.text:
In other words, refugees are part
of the global economy

509.45.text: and part of global value chains

511.55.text:
even when they are in camps
and settlements.

515.38.text:
The second myth we were able
to challenge was the idea

519.01.text:
We found for example that in Kampala
21% of refugees run businesses

527.42.text:
And of those they employ, 40% are
Ugandan nationals of the host country.

533.05.text:
In other words, refugees
are creating jobs for citizens.

And what we also found was,

a rode in central Kampala
where a number of Somali women

They've created a social insurance
mechanism called an ayuuto

where they pay in a share of
their income

551.67.text:
and if somebody has a challenge,
a health problem,

555.12.text:
somebody has a member
of their family who is in difficulty,

557.75.text:
that ayuuto pays out, providing
an informal social support network

566.28.text:
The third myth we were able
to challenge with this research

569.15.text: was that all refugees do the same thing.

571.22.text:
There is a view in Uganda that
all refugees are farmers.

574.20.text:
If you gave them a plod of land,

576.97.text:
But actually there's huge diversity,

580.49.text:
The average income may be quite low.
We found it to be

583.62.text:
29 US dollars a month
for refugees in Uganda.

586.83.text:
But around that there
was a whole range.

588.90.text:
Some did very badly and others,
although outliers,

595.44.text:
And we found a range of livelihood
activities, some really creative,

601.18.text:
This is Demuke, a Congolese
refugee who, arriving in Nakivale

606.68.text:
didn't have a trade, didn't have skills
that he could bring,

610.66.text:
but decided he wanted to be
a documentary filmmaker.

614.44.text:
And with friends he set up
a documentary filmmaking team,

618.22.text: and made a couple of films for us,

620.04.text:
but he's also set up a community
radio station.

We've seen Somalis developing

629.16.text:
between the camp

631.55.text:
We've seen examples of computer
games parlors

using recycled television screens,

The fourth myth we were able
to challenge was that

646.34.text:
they use mobile phones

The tragedy is that in the settlements,

But they don't just use these

657.14.text: with friends or for social networking.

It's a core part of their primary
income generating activities.

664.00.text:
They use it to transfer business

to create the networks that

there is innovation

As I found, if you pedal

but they're not quite as silly

The fifth myth is that refugees

We found in Uganda that less
than 1% of refugee households

704.41.text:
had no source of independent
income generating activity.

708.49.text:
They're not sitting passively, reliant

711.88.text:
they are getting on with it

This photograph illustrates a social
enterprise called MakaPad.

And the MakaPad is a female
sanitary product,

723.53.text:
and it's been developed by a Ugandan

and he's placed his factories in a

And he employs refugees
to produce the products

738.81.text:
and then they're bought
by the UN Refugee Agency

It's creating jobs for refugees
but also a sustainable business

747.82.text:
for a Ugandan national that's been scaled

753.02.text:
But the question is,
what does this mean more broadly?

756.98.text:
Well we found interesting findings
in our data analysis

760.80.text:
that highlight for instance
what explains variation

766.17.text: Why do some do better than others?

767.84.text:
Why are some refugees' incomes
higher than others?

770.74.text:
And we found a number
of really interesting things.

773.23.text:
One of the most important factors
is the regulatory environment.

777.10.text:
In Uganda we were able to collect data
from the capital city,

780.34.text:
from long standing camps
and settlements,

782.86.text:
and new emergency camps
and settlements.

785.05.text:
And they have slightly different
regulatory frames

788.42.text:
But what we found there
and looking more broadly

791.26.text:
is that the greater the economic opportunity
and freedom refugees have,

795.32.text:
the better able they are
to help themselves

797.42.text:
and make contributions
to the host economy.

802.07.text: We found data on returns to education.

804.71.text:
For each year of education
a refugee receives,

808.87.text:
their income goes up on average
3.3% per year.

813.65.text:
And that increases with each stage
of education.

816.38.text:
For primary education
it's a 2.4% increase per year.

821.05.text:
For secondary education
it's a 4.5% increase.

824.99.text:
For tertiary education you get 6.2%
higher income per year of your career

831.39.text:
as a result of each year
in the university system.

834.81.text:
There are other factors
that of course matter.

836.77.text:
Occupation matters. There's a massive 
gap in terms of gender

843.40.text:
And the years in exile
diminish your income potential.

847.11.text:
The longer you are in exile, the more
your income is likely to decline.

851.32.text:
And we're trying to take that work
from Uganda and do it now in Kenya

854.93.text:
to compare between a country
that doesn't offer the right to work,

857.45.text:
to be able to say, "This is a cost to you
of not giving refugees

863.56.text:
But what about the Syrian context?
How does it apply there?

867.63.text:
At the moment Syrian refugees
like Amira and her family,

871.74.text:
face an almost impossible choice.
They lack these kinds of freedoms,

876.33.text:
and that choice assuming
that they can't go home,

879.28.text:
and they really can't
because of the situation in Syria,

882.17.text:
they face three almost
impossible choices.

886.47.text:
The first choice is to go to a camp
and this is the choice taken by just

893.44.text:
They can go to camps like Zaatari
where they don't have the right to work,

897.61.text:
where business is pretty much
prohibited and highly regulated,

901.84.text:
where at night you can you still hear
the sound of mortar shells

904.95.text: from the other side of the border.

906.59.text:
The second option, chosen
by around 75% of Syrians,

910.99.text:
is to go to an urban area
in a neighboring country,

913.83.text:
Amman or Beirut. But there, with very severe
restrictions on the right to work,

919.58.text:
where people have used up their savings or
the little capital they bring with them,

925.22.text:
And so that leaves the third
and final option, which is to embark

929.78.text:
on very dangerous journeys,
and that's what we're seeing in Europe.

933.65.text: But it doesn't have to be that way.

936.51.text:
The challenge is that
not all host countries

940.02.text: take the approach that Uganda takes.

942.45.text:
They won't open up their economies
to refugees.

947.79.text: Last April I travelled with my colleague

950.38.text:
the development economist Paul Collier,
to Jordan,

953.46.text:
and there we brainstormed an idea to
give Syrian refugees the right to work

960.65.text:
And the idea emerged
because just 15 minutes away

964.58.text:
from the Zaatari refugee camp,
home to 83,000 Syrian refugees,

970.60.text:
The King Hussein Bin Talal
development area.

973.27.text:
And the government spent around 100 million
dollars connecting it to the electricity grid,

978.51.text:
connecting it to the road network.
But it lacks a couple of things:

984.38.text:
So we wondered, what would it be like
if that could be opened up

988.01.text:
as an opportunity for refugees
to get access to education and jobs.

991.91.text:
And we put the idea forwards in an
article that we published in Foreign Affairs

996.20.text:
suggesting we could potentially
be incubating

998.47.text:
the post-conflict economy of Syria
by providing those opportunities.

1002.26.text: If Europe could provide trade concessions.

1004.49.text:
If Jordan could provide work permits.
If businesses could invest.

1008.15.text:
And that idea has been picked up
by King Abdullah, David Cameron,

1012.12.text:
the World Bank and a pilot
is about to begin this summer.

1022.14.text:
And so, finally, as I start to get
into Al Gore time,

1027.34.text:
what does an overall vision
potentially look like?

1031.24.text:
What is the vision that Europe
is currently lacking

1033.81.text: that we could begin to put forwards?

1036.06.text:
I think the key to getting this right,
to having sustainable solutions

1039.98.text:
at scale for refugees, is to recognize
that we can all be better off

1044.08.text:
with economic opportunity,
with seeing this as a relationship not just

1047.17.text:
between states and refugees
but between states, markets

1050.93.text:
and refugees, and with a role
for social enterprise.

1054.40.text:
The solutions though have to be found
at three levels.

1057.15.text:
Primarily most refugees are not
in Europe,

1060.30.text:
they're in developing regions of
the world where about 86% are based.

1064.79.text:
The refugee problem in terms
of numbers is not unmanageable.

1069.05.text:
Just 0.3% of the world's population
are refugees.

1072.61.text:
It's the geographical concentration
which is a challenge.

1075.99.text:
Just 10 countries host nearly 60%
of the world's refugees

1079.45.text: and it's there that we need solutions.

1081.18.text:
And those solutions have to be
to support the development

1084.06.text:
or border locations, underdeveloped
in many host countries but with the potential

1088.60.text:
to create opportunities for hosts
and refugees alongside one another.

1092.60.text:
And at one end of the spectrum,
the Uganda model,

1095.67.text:
it's about temporary integration
and full participation.

1098.90.text:
But where that's not possible it needs
to be about incubation, about jobs,

1103.07.text:
education, human flourishing,
and seeing beyond the camp model.

1107.66.text:
At the second level we need to also
think about the journeys

1110.94.text:
that the minority take onwards, and
there are models for addressing this.

1114.78.text:
An idea that can be developed
is for humanitarian visas,

1118.54.text:
rather than making people resort
to smugglers to travel from Turkey

1122.10.text:
to Greece, or rather than pushing them
back through coercion

1125.35.text:
and effectively using violence
against those people,

1127.91.text:
why not allow refugees to go
to consulates or embassies,

1131.42.text:
get a visa that allows them to travel
on a budget airline

1135.08.text:
from Bodrum to Frankfurt
or Stockholm and when they get there

1139.97.text:
There are ways in which we can save
lives, undercut the markets for smugglers,

1145.42.text:
Brazil has embarked on a pilot
for humanitarian visas

1148.59.text:
and integrated around 10,000 Syrians
through this scheme.

1152.39.text:
And in Europe it's not as hard
as Europe is making it seem.

1156.34.text:
What we need for those that come here
as a last resort,

1159.62.text:
is a way of fairly
distributing responsibility,

1162.35.text:
of ensuring that all 28 EU
member states

1166.04.text: participate in a fair and just scheme.

1168.99.text:
And it's possible to do
using ideas from the market.

1172.61.text: The idea developed by the Nobel Prize winning economist Al Roth,

1176.42.text:
for preference matching
could allows us to ask refugees

1179.43.text:
where they want to go but also ask
governments what their preferences are

1183.33.text:
in terms of skills, in terms
of the types of people they want,

1186.54.text:
with caveats for vulnerability
and family unity and such criteria.

1191.10.text:
That idea of preference matching
has been used in other areas

1194.56.text:
to match medical students
with residency,

1197.63.text: to match organ donors with recipients,

1201.07.text:
for the basis of algorithms
for dating websites.

1204.57.text:
But we rarely ask refugees
where they want to go

1207.33.text: and we rarely give them choices.

1209.07.text: So I think we can have a new vision.

1211.06.text:
And as part of this it should be one
of human flourishing.

1214.94.text:
There's another area of social life
in which people go temporarily,

1219.39.text:
and when they're there temporarily
we give them opportunities

1223.09.text:
to learn, to flourish as human beings,
and that's the university campus.

1228.01.text:
Now, of course some people end up in
protracted university situations like me

1234.14.text:
but if we could recognize that
it's about incubating human talent,

1238.16.text:
enabling people to flourish,
they will contribute to our societies

1241.64.text:
while they're here and they will rebuild
their societies when they go back.

1245.36.text:
What I've argued is very simple,
almost embarrassingly simple,

1249.84.text: is that these people are human beings

1252.47.text:
and as such they will able
to help themselves

1255.09.text:
and make a contribution
if we let them.

1259.07.text:
If you're interested
in what I've told you about

1260.91.text:
we've published two very
accessible reports

1263.16.text:
on refugee economies
and refugee innovation.
